elements.content: A novel metal–organic framework {Zn2(tpt)2(tad)2·H2O} (tpt = 2,4,6-tri­(pyridin-4-yl)-1,3,5-triazine, H2tda = 2,5-thiophene dicarboxylic acid) with a 3-fold interpenetrating 3D framework was successfully synthesized under hydrothermal conditions. As expected, 1 displays excellent luminescence and can stably exist in different pure organic solvents and acid–base solution. 1 can be considered as an ultrasensitive sensor for detection of Fe3+ ions and PA with high selectivity by fluorescence quenching behaviors. Meanwhile, the fluorescence test plates show the visible color change of Fe3+ ions which can be easily observed by the naked eye in the detection process, which makes Fe3+ ions more easily recognized than various metal ions. In addition, the mechanism of fluorescence quenching is also further discussed.

elements.content: Nowadays, the effective detection of nitroaromatic compounds (NACs) and metal ions has drawn great interest due to its importance in human health and homeland security. NACs has been recognized as a kind of hazardous environmental pollutant because it is difficult to remove or degrade, but it is still extensively used in a variety of industries including dyes, fireworks, and pharmaceuticals. 2,4,6-Trinitriphenol (PA) as an important member of the NACs family, which is a more powerful explosive than 2,4,6-trinitrotoluene (TNT), has been widely used in fireworks and rocket fuels and in the manufacture of landmines. Massive amounts of PA are discharged into the environment from chemical industries, which has caused a series of problems for wildlife and humans. However, the iron anion (Fe3+) has extensive applications in industry and plays key roles in various biochemical processes at a cellular level. However, excess Fe3+ can be harmful to nucleic acids and proteins because Fe3+ can catalyze the production of reactive oxygen species by the Fenton reaction. Therefore, developing highly efficient methods for quick, reliable, and robust detection of PA and Fe3+ ions is of great significance for human health and the environment.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Nowadays, the effective detection of nitroaromatic compounds (NACs) and metal ions has drawn great interest due to its importance in human health and homeland security. NACs has been recognized as a kind of hazardous environmental pollutant because it is difficult to remove or degrade, but it is still extensively used in a variety of industries including dyes, fireworks, and pharmaceuticals. 2,4,6-Trinitriphenol (PA) as an important member of the NACs family, which is a more powerful explosive than 2,4,6-trinitrotoluene (TNT), has been widely used in fireworks and rocket fuels and in the manufacture of landmines. Massive amounts of PA are discharged into the environment from chemical industries, which has caused a series of problems for wildlife and humans. However, the iron anion (Fe3+) has extensive applications in industry and plays key roles in various biochemical processes at a cellular level. However, excess Fe3+ can be harmful to nucleic acids and proteins because Fe3+ can catalyze the production of reactive oxygen species by the Fenton reaction. Therefore, developing highly efficient methods for quick, reliable, and robust detection of PA and Fe3+ ions is of great significance for human health and the environment.

elements.content: Recently, luminescent metal–organic frameworks (LMOFs) have raised increasing amounts of attention due to their remarkable sensitivity, highly selectivity, operability simplicity, and dual compatibility in solid and solution media. In order to achieve fluorescent sensing which is highly responsive to analyte, an efficient strategy to design and synthesize the MOFs with excellence fluorescent property is to select an organic ligand with a π-electron-conjugated system for the following reasons. First, the organic ligand bound by metal anions in MOFs will reduce the nonradioactive transition and show strong emission. Second, the capillary effect of a channel of MOFs can preconcentrate the dilute analyte and give rise to better selectivity. Furthermore, specific functional groups can be easily introduced into MOFs to interact with the chosen analytes and to improve the selectivity. Recently, a large number of fluorescent chemosensors based on MOFs have been investigated for the detection of NACs and metal ions. However, to the best of our knowledge, it is still a large challenge to rationally design and synthesize the MOF-based chemosensors with high sensitivity and selectivity for analytes in aqueous.
elements.clean_text: Recently, luminescent metal-organic frameworks (LMOFs) have raised increasing amounts of attention due to their remarkable sensitivity, highly selectivity, operability simplicity, and dual compatibility in solid and solution media. In order to achieve fluorescent sensing which is highly responsive to analyte, an efficient strategy to design and synthesize the MOFs with excellence fluorescent property is to select an organic ligand with a π-electron-conjugated system for the following reasons. First, the organic ligand bound by metal anions in MOFs will reduce the nonradioactive transition and show strong emission. Second, the capillary effect of a channel of MOFs can preconcentrate the dilute analyte and give rise to better selectivity. Furthermore, specific functional groups can be easily introduced into MOFs to interact with the chosen analytes and to improve the selectivity. Recently, a large number of fluorescent chemosensors based on MOFs have been investigated for the detection of NACs and metal ions. However, to the best of our knowledge, it is still a large challenge to rationally design and synthesize the MOF-based chemosensors with high sensitivity and selectivity for analytes in aqueous.

elements.content: On the basis of above discussion, in order to obtain the MOF-based fluorescent probe which demonstrates unique sensitivity and selectivity for analytes in water solution, we selected thiophene-2,5-dicarboxylic acid (H2tda) and 2,4,6-tri­(pyridin-4-yl)-1,3,5-triazine (tpt) as ligands and Zn2+ as a metal center to construct MOFs with the reasons as follows: (a) Zinc with a d10 electronic configuration is an outstanding candidate for photoluminescence materials and is usually used to construct MOFs with excellent fluorescence properties. (b) H2tda not only shows as an attractive bridging performance which can be attributed the angle of 120° between two carboxyl groups but also exhibits the excellent electron-transferring ability due to electron richness in thiophene ring. (c) tpt is π-electronic conjugated organic compound and has a rigid structure which is favorable for the stability of MOFs with excellent fluorescence properties. (d) The conjugated structure of tpt and H2tda is beneficial to electronic transition leading to the enhancement of photoluminescence. Therefore, the MOFs built by H2tda, tpt, and Zn2+ will show intriguing architectures and topologies with excellent luminescence properties that can be used for the detection of NACs and metal ions. On the basis of above strategy, we report a highly luminescent MOF [Zn2(tpt)­(tda)2]·H2O (1) possessing a four-connected uninodal net. 1 can serve as a promising dual-functional fluorescence sensor for detection and recognition of PA and Fe3+ ions via fluorescence quenching with remarkable selectivity and sensitivity in aqueous solution. Furthermore, the visible color changes in the detection process make Fe3+ easy to distinguish among various metal ions by the naked eye.

elements.content: All reagents and solvents were commercially available and used without further purification. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements were carried out on a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation. Infrared (IR) spectra were measured on a Spectrum 100 spectrometer using KBr pellets (400–4000 cm–1). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out between room temperature and 400 °C under a flow of N2 at a heating rate of 10 °C min–1. The fluorescence emission spectra were measured on a Cary Eclipse Luminescent spectrophotometer. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were performed on a PerkinElmer 2400. The UV/vis absorption spectra were recorded at room temperature on a Cary 4000 UV/vis spectrometer. Point symbol and topological analyses were conducted by using the TOPOS program package.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All reagents and solvents were commercially available and used without further purification. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements were carried out on a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation. Infrared (IR) spectra were measured on a Spectrum 100 spectrometer using KBr pellets (400-4000 cm-1). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out between room temperature and 400 °C under a flow of N2 at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. The fluorescence emission spectra were measured on a Cary Eclipse Luminescent spectrophotometer. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were performed on a PerkinElmer 2400. The UV/vis absorption spectra were recorded at room temperature on a Cary 4000 UV/vis spectrometer. Point symbol and topological analyses were conducted by using the TOPOS program package.

elements.content: A solid mixture of tpt (0.015 mmol, 0.009g), H2tda (0.03 mmol, 0.010g), and ZnSO4·6H2O (0.035 mmol, 0.021) were dissolved into 6 mL of solvent mixture containing water and CH3CN (5:1), then treated by ultrasonication for 10 min. Next, the mixture solution was transformed to a 20 mL Teflon reactor and heated at 150 °C for 72 h. White block crystals were obtained after slowly cooling down room temperature, and the yield is up to 63.2% based on ZnSO4·6H2O. Anal. calcd (%) for C30H18N6O9S2Zn2: C 43.26%; H 3.65%; N 22.36%. Found: C 43.53%; H 3.67%; N 22.23%.

Synthesis

A solid mixture of tpt (0.015 mmol, 0.009g), H2tda (0.03 mmol, 0.010g), and ZnSO4⋅6H2O (0.035 mmol, 0.021) were dissolved into 6 mL of solvent mixture containing water and CH3CN (5:1), then treated by ultrasonication for 10 min. Next, the mixture solution was transformed to a 20 mL Teflon reactor and heated at 150 °C for 72 h. White block crystals were obtained after slowly cooling down room temperature, and the yield is up to 63.2% based on ZnSO4⋅6H2O. Anal. calcd (%) for C30H18N6O9S2Zn2: C 43.26%; H 3.65%; N 22.36%. Found: C 43.53%; H 3.67%; N 22.23%.

elements.content: All data were recorded on an Agilent technology SuperNova Eos dual system with a (Cu Kα, λ = 1.54184 Å) microfocus source and focusing multilayer mirror optics at room temperature. The structures were solved and refined using the full matrix least-squares method based on F2 using the SHELXS-2018 and SHELXL-2018 programs. The carboxyl group (O5–C7–O6) of tda2– anion is disordered and splits into two parts with the site occupancy factors being 0.55 and 0.45. The disordered carboxyl group was refined anisotropically. The ratios of the maximum and minimum displacement parameters for the disordered atoms were larger than 2 and were restrained. The hydrogen atoms of ligands were localized in their calculated positions and refined using the riding model. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Further details of the X-ray structural analyses are given in . Selected bond lengths and bond angles of 1 are listed in Table S1.

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic P21/c space group, displaying a novel 3-fold interpenetrated 3D architecture. The asymmetric unit of 1 contains two crystallographically unique Zn­(II) ions, two tda2– anions, one tpt, and one lattice water (Figure S1). The Zn1 center exhibits two kinds of geometry, distorted tetrahedron (ca. 55%) and distorted tetragonal pyramid (ca. 45%), because of the disorder of carboxyl groups of tda2– anion. In the disordered tetrahedron/tetragonal pyramid, the Zn­(II) center is four-/five-coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from two different tpt ligands and two/three oxygen atoms from two different tda2– anions. The distances of Zn–N [2.046(2)-2.067(2) Å] and Zn–O [1.901(6)-2.271(13) Å] are in the normal ranges of those observed in reported Zn (II) compounds. The central Zn2 center displays a distorted tetragonal pyramid, defined by four oxygen atoms [O8, O4iii, O3iv, O7v, symmetry codes (iii) 1 + x, 0.5 – y, −0.5 + y; (iv) 2 – x, −0.5 + y, 1.5 – z; (v) 3 – x, −y, 1 – z] from four different tda2– anions a least-squares plane with average deviation 0.008 Å, and one nitrogen atom [N2ii; symmetry codes: (ii) 1 – x, −0.5 + y, 0.5 – z] from tpt ligand in the axial sites. the Zn–N distances and Zn–O distances are 2.061(18) Å and 2.027(2)–2.041(2) Å, respectively, which are in the normal ranges of those observed in reported Zn­(II) complexes. Two adjacent Zn2 atoms are bridged by four μ2-η1:η1-carboxylate groups from four tda2– anions into a paddle wheel dimeric [Zn2(CO2)4] with C 4 symmetry, in which the Zn–Zn distance is 3.013 Å. As shown in , the disordered tda2– anions are two linkers and use two carboxylate groups to bridge the Zn1 centers and the [Zn2(CO2)4] dimers. The tpt ligand is a three-way tube linker and adopts the μ3-coordination mode to coordinate with two Zn1 centers and one [Zn2(CO2)4] dimers. Therefore, a two-dimensional (2D) sheet structure with two types of caves is formed. Cave A is a pentagon constructed by two Zn1 atoms, one dimer, one tda2– anion, and two tpt ligands with the side lengths of 1.48, 7.92, 7.42, 7.58, and 9.36 Å. However, cave B is a hexagon formed by two Zn1 atoms and two dimers, two tpt ligands, and two tda2– anions with the side lengths of 9.41, 10.24, 7.57, 9.07, 10.28, and 7.29 Å.

Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure Description

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic P21/c space group, displaying a novel 3-fold interpenetrated 3D architecture. The asymmetric unit of 1 contains two crystallographically unique Zn(II) ions, two tda2- anions, one tpt, and one lattice water (Figure S1). The Zn1 center exhibits two kinds of geometry, distorted tetrahedron (ca. 55%) and distorted tetragonal pyramid (ca. 45%), because of the disorder of carboxyl groups of tda2- anion. In the disordered tetrahedron/tetragonal pyramid, the Zn(II) center is four-/five-coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from two different tpt ligands and two/three oxygen atoms from two different tda2- anions. The distances of Zn-N [2.046(2)-2.067(2) Å] and Zn-O [1.901(6)-2.271(13) Å] are in the normal ranges of those observed in reported Zn (II) compounds. The central Zn2 center displays a distorted tetragonal pyramid, defined by four oxygen atoms [O8, O4iii, O3iv, O7v, symmetry codes (iii) 1 + x, 0.5 - y, -0.5 + y; (iv) 2 - x, -0.5 + y, 1.5 - z; (v) 3 - x, -y, 1 - z] from four different tda2- anions a least-squares plane with average deviation 0.008 Å, and one nitrogen atom [N2ii; symmetry codes: (ii) 1 - x, -0.5 + y, 0.5 - z] from tpt ligand in the axial sites. the Zn-N distances and Zn-O distances are 2.061(18) Å and 2.027(2)-2.041(2) Å, respectively, which are in the normal ranges of those observed in reported Zn(II) complexes. Two adjacent Zn2 atoms are bridged by four μ2-η1:η1-carboxylate groups from four tda2- anions into a paddle wheel dimeric [Zn2(CO2)4] with C 4 symmetry, in which the Zn-Zn distance is 3.013 Å. As shown in , the disordered tda2- anions are two linkers and use two carboxylate groups to bridge the Zn1 centers and the [Zn2(CO2)4] dimers. The tpt ligand is a three-way tube linker and adopts the μ3-coordination mode to coordinate with two Zn1 centers and one [Zn2(CO2)4] dimers. Therefore, a two-dimensional (2D) sheet structure with two types of caves is formed. Cave A is a pentagon constructed by two Zn1 atoms, one dimer, one tda2- anion, and two tpt ligands with the side lengths of 1.48, 7.92, 7.42, 7.58, and 9.36 Å. However, cave B is a hexagon formed by two Zn1 atoms and two dimers, two tpt ligands, and two tda2- anions with the side lengths of 9.41, 10.24, 7.57, 9.07, 10.28, and 7.29 Å.

elements.content: 2D sheet of 1 featured two type of caves, the pentagonal cave A and the hexangular cave B.

elements.content: The 2D sheets are further pillared by the orderly tda2– anions to construct the 3D framework. The separation between the adjacent sheets is about 10.2 Å (). A feature of 1 is the interlamellar space being separated by orderly tad2– anions and forming two types of tunnels along b axis. The dimensions of A and B are 7.1 × 10.2 Å2 and 10.2 × 14.5 Å2, respectively. Despite the nature of the 3-fold interpenetration, 1 still forms 1D open tunnels with the dimensions ca. 3.2 Å × 7.1 Å in which the lattice water molecules are trapped by O–H···O hydrogen bonds.

elements.content: From the topological point of view, if each Zn1 center, being connected by two tda2– anions and two tpt ligands, can be considered a four-connected node, then each dimer can simplified as a six-connected node, because it is connected by two tpt ligands and four tda2– anions, each tda2– anion is simplified by a linear linker, and tpt ligand is simplified by a three-way tube linker. This framework can be simplified into a 3,4,6-c net with Schläfli symbols {53}2{54·62}2{56·64·72·93} (a). As far as we know, this type of topology has not been reported yet. Because of the spacious nature of the single framework, the tunnels in a single 3D framework can be interpenetrated by two identical frameworks and generate a 3-fold interpenetrating 3D framework (b).

elements.content: The PXRD pattern of 1 matches well with the simulated patterns based on the single-crystal construction, indicating that 1 has high phase purity (Figure S2). In addition, the IR spectrum of 1 was studied, as shown in the Figure S3; the strong absorptions at 1646 and 1561 cm–1 were attributed to the CC and CN stretching vibrations, respectively. The peak at 1460 cm–1 was resulted from CO vibrations. The strong peak at 1365 cm–1 in 1 was C–C vibration; another sharp peak at 772 cm–1 was characteristic of meta substitution of dicarboxylic acid.
elements.clean_text:
PXRD, IR, and Thermal Property

The PXRD pattern of 1 matches well with the simulated patterns based on the single-crystal construction, indicating that 1 has high phase purity (Figure S2). In addition, the IR spectrum of 1 was studied, as shown in the Figure S3; the strong absorptions at 1646 and 1561 cm-1 were attributed to the CC and CN stretching vibrations, respectively. The peak at 1460 cm-1 was resulted from CO vibrations. The strong peak at 1365 cm-1 in 1 was C-C vibration; another sharp peak at 772 cm-1 was characteristic of meta substitution of dicarboxylic acid.

elements.content: To investigate stability, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of 1 was carried out under a nitrogen environment, and the heating rate was 10 °C/min. As shown in the Figure S4, the TGA curve of 1 displays three steps of weight loss. The first weight loss ranging from 30 to 100 °C is connected with the water molecule adsorbed on the surface of the crystal. The second weight loss of 2.27% (ca. 2.25%) from 256 to 337 °C is attributed to the loss of one free crystal water molecule. The last weight loss step after 337 °C corresponds to the collapse of framework.

elements.content: Stable existence in acid–based solution with different pHs is a test criterion for the performance of sensors. 1 was immersed into the acid–base solution with different pH values for 12 h, filtered, and the PXRD measured. As shown in FigureS5, the patterns of 1 before and after pretreatment are closely matched, which implies that the framework of 1 still remains intact. The experimental results show that 1 has excellent tolerance of acid–base treatment. Meanwhile, the PXRD patterns of 1 in various organic solvents were also investigated. As shown in Figure S6, the results display that 1 can maintain integrity of framework after dealing with organic solvents. Furthermore, the SEM imagine of 1shows that the surface of MOF material after treating with different solution has no change compared with blank sample, which further implying that 1 has excellent stability (Figure S7).
elements.clean_text:
Sability of 1 in Acid-Base Solution

Stable existence in acid-based solution with different pHs is a test criterion for the performance of sensors. 1 was immersed into the acid-base solution with different pH values for 12 h, filtered, and the PXRD measured. As shown in FigureS5, the patterns of 1 before and after pretreatment are closely matched, which implies that the framework of 1 still remains intact. The experimental results show that 1 has excellent tolerance of acid-base treatment. Meanwhile, the PXRD patterns of 1 in various organic solvents were also investigated. As shown in Figure S6, the results display that 1 can maintain integrity of framework after dealing with organic solvents. Furthermore, the SEM imagine of 1shows that the surface of MOF material after treating with different solution has no change compared with blank sample, which further implying that 1 has excellent stability (Figure S7).

elements.content: In view that 1 was constructed from π-conjugated ligands and d10 metal centers, we speculated that it may be a good photoactive material, so the solid-state photoluminescent of the free ligands and 1 were investigated at room temperature. As shown in the Figure S8, the free tpt ligand and 1 display a strong emission peak at 394 nm (λex = 282 nm) and 386 nm (λex = 280 nm), respectively. H2tda ligand shows an emission peak at 365 nm (λex = 285 nm). We can find that tpt plays significant role in fluorescence of 1. The result shows that the emission band of 1 may be attributed to the intraligand π* → π and π* → n transition due to the d10 nature of Zn2+ ions. Furthermore, the liquid luminescence properties of 1 and tpt (molar ratio = 1:1) were investigated (Figure S9). Compared with free tpt ligands, the emission intensity of 1 was significantly enhanced which may be explained by the nonradiative relaxation in the ligands reduce leading to the increasing of emission after coordinating to central metal ions (Zn2+), besides which can be related to the increasing electronic communication between the adjacent coordinated ligands molecules resulting from the metal center. In addition, 2 mg of 1 was separated into acid–based solutions with different pHs and fluorescence spectra recorded. As shown in Figure S10, after treatment with the acid–based solution, the fluorescence intensity of 1 is as good as that of the original, suggesting that the pH has no influence on the fluorescence of 1.
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescent Properties

In view that 1 was constructed from π-conjugated ligands and d10 metal centers, we speculated that it may be a good photoactive material, so the solid-state photoluminescent of the free ligands and 1 were investigated at room temperature. As shown in the Figure S8, the free tpt ligand and 1 display a strong emission peak at 394 nm (λex = 282 nm) and 386 nm (λex = 280 nm), respectively. H2tda ligand shows an emission peak at 365 nm (λex = 285 nm). We can find that tpt plays significant role in fluorescence of 1. The result shows that the emission band of 1 may be attributed to the intraligand π* → π and π* → n transition due to the d10 nature of Zn2+ ions. Furthermore, the liquid luminescence properties of 1 and tpt (molar ratio = 1:1) were investigated (Figure S9). Compared with free tpt ligands, the emission intensity of 1 was significantly enhanced which may be explained by the nonradiative relaxation in the ligands reduce leading to the increasing of emission after coordinating to central metal ions (Zn2+), besides which can be related to the increasing electronic communication between the adjacent coordinated ligands molecules resulting from the metal center. In addition, 2 mg of 1 was separated into acid-based solutions with different pHs and fluorescence spectra recorded. As shown in Figure S10, after treatment with the acid-based solution, the fluorescence intensity of 1 is as good as that of the original, suggesting that the pH has no influence on the fluorescence of 1.

elements.content: Furthermore, the fluorescence property of 1 in different organic molecules was determined. As shown in Figure S11, different solvents have different effects on the luminescence intensity of 1 which can be attributed to solvent effects. Obviously, the luminescence of 1 was completely quenched by nitrobenzene (NB) solution compared with other solvents which implied that 1 can be served as fluorescence probe to recognize NACs in aqueous phase.

elements.content: Considering that NB displays completely quenching effect on fluorescence intensity of 1, we further investigate its sensitive and selective ability toward different NACs. Thus, a series of fluorescence titration experiments were carried out by gradually dropping the concentration of different NACs (5 mM) into a suspension of 1, including NB, p-nitrophenol (4-NP), 2,4-dinitrotoluene (2,4-DNT), m-nitrotoluene (m-NT), m-dinitrobenzene (m-DNB), p-nitrotoluene (p-NT), o-nitrotoluene (o-NT), picric acid (PA), and o-nitrotoluene (o-NT). The details of the fluorescence intensity of 1 after addition of different NACs were recorded in Figures S12 and a. It is obvious that the fluorescence of 1 with the addition of PA was almost completely quenched in contrast with other NACs, the quenching efficiency reached 96% (Q = (I 0 – I i )/I 0 × 100%) when the concentration of PA was to 80 μM (). The results show that 1 can selectively detect PA by the property of luminance quenching in aqueous solution.

Detection of Nitro Compounds

Considering that NB displays completely quenching effect on fluorescence intensity of 1, we further investigate its sensitive and selective ability toward different NACs. Thus, a series of fluorescence titration experiments were carried out by gradually dropping the concentration of different NACs (5 mM) into a suspension of 1, including NB, p-nitrophenol (4-NP), 2,4-dinitrotoluene (2,4-DNT), m-nitrotoluene (m-NT), m-dinitrobenzene (m-DNB), p-nitrotoluene (p-NT), o-nitrotoluene (o-NT), picric acid (PA), and o-nitrotoluene (o-NT). The details of the fluorescence intensity of 1 after addition of different NACs were recorded in Figures S12 and a. It is obvious that the fluorescence of 1 with the addition of PA was almost completely quenched in contrast with other NACs, the quenching efficiency reached 96% (Q = (I 0 - I  i )/I 0 × 100%) when the concentration of PA was to 80 μM (). The results show that 1 can selectively detect PA by the property of luminance quenching in aqueous solution.

elements.content: The quenching efficiency between PA and 1 can be quantitatively calculated using the Stern–Volmer (S–V) equation: (I 0/I) = 1 + K SV [Q], where I 0 and I is the emission intensity of 1 before and after addition of PA, respectively, K sv is quenching constant, and [Q] is the concentration of PA. As shown in b, the S–V plot displays linear relation at a low concentration of PA, while it shows upward bending trend at high concentration of PA, which can be attributed to the self-absorption between MOFs and analytes. At low concentration, K SV is up to 7.8 × 104 M–1, which was comparable to the previous reported MOF for detection of PA. Meanwhile, the limit of detection was further calculated according to the corresponding the data. As shown in Figure S13, the value of detection limit is up to 2.56 × 10–6 M, suggesting that 1 can act as an excellent sensor to detect PA with high selectivity and sensitivity in aqueous solution.

To better understand the reason behind fluorescence quenching of 1 in the presence of PA, the quenching mechanisms were deeply studied. Usually, the common accepted mechanisms are as follows: (a) photoinduced electron transfer (PET), (b) the collapse of framework of 1 after introducing analytes, and (c) resonance energy transfer (RET). The most of NACs are belong to electrodeficient compounds with low LUMO energy, which can easily accept excited electron from electron-rich fluorophores (MOFs) through donor–acceptor (D-A) interactions leading to fluorescence quenching. The HOMO–LUMO energies of ligands and all NACs were calculated using density functional theory (DFT) at the B3LYP/6-31+G* level. The LUMO energy of NACs is lower, so the ability of NACs to accept electrons become stronger and the fluorescence quenching more significant. As shown in Figure S14 and Table S2, compared with other NACs, the LUMO energy of PA is lowest, and the excited electron of 1 can be more easily accepted by the LUMO of PA, which is in accord with the result of the titration experiment. Furthermore, the cyclic voltammetry (CV) between 1 and PA was in favor of the PET theory in experiment. Platinum, glassy carbon, and Ag/AgCl were selected as auxiliary, working, and reference electrodes, respectively. A 1 M KCl solution was used as supporting electrolyte, and we removed O2 dealing with N2 at room temperature. As shown in , compared with the single system of 1, the reduction current of 1 after addition of PA was significantly enhanced, suggesting that the electron transition took place between analyte and electron material (Zn–MOF). In addition, the reduction potential of hydrogen evolution (−0.455 V) disappeared, and the reduction potential of PA, −0.679 V, was presented under UV light at 235 nm in the presence of PA, which indicated that the excited electron of the electron material (Zn–MOF) was accepted by PA. The reduction of PA plays key role in the whole system, rather than H+. The experimental results matched with the phenomenon of fluorescence quenching of 1 resulting from PA, so PET theory can contribute to the luminescence quenching of PA to 1.

elements.content: Next, the PXRD pattern of 1 was agreement with the original one, so the framework of 1 still maintains integrity after detection of PA, suggesting that the fluorescence quenching of 1 did not attribute to the collapse of crystal framework (Figure S15). On the basis of previous research, resonance energy transfer which is dependent on the degree of overlap between the absorption of analytes and emission band of fluorophore is another main mechanism for the luminescence quenching of sensors. The extent of overlap gets wider, the efficiency of fluorescence quenching is higher. Therefore, the UV–vis spectra of different NACs were monitored and recorded in detail in the Figure S16. The result shows that PA has maximum overlap with the emission spectral of 1, fitting well with the result of quenching efficiency. In addition, the absorption of p-NT and o-Np also has a partial overlap with 1 causing a slight quenching response to the luminescence intensity of 1. This demonstrated that 1 can selectively and sensitively detect PA, which may mainly be attributed to the combination of PET and RET.

elements.content: Metal ions play essential roles in biological systems and human health, so it is significant for us to accurate and real-time detection of them. The remarkable fluorescence property of 1 in liquid solution encourages us to explore its potential ability in the field of detecting metal ions. Various aqueous solution of M­(NO3) x (0.1 M) containing different metal ions (M x+ = Li+, K+, Na+, Ca2+, Ba2+, Mg2+, Hg2+, Mn2+, Zn2+, Al3+, Ni2+, Co2+, Cu2+, Fe3+, and Ag+) was separately dropped into suspension of 1 and tested the luminescence spectral under consistent conditions. As shown in Figure S17, only Fe3+ ions display a significant quenching effect on the emission intensity of 1, suggesting the high selectivity of 1 for specific detection of Fe3+ ions in water solution.
elements.clean_text:
Detection of Metal Ions

Metal ions play essential roles in biological systems and human health, so it is significant for us to accurate and real-time detection of them. The remarkable fluorescence property of 1 in liquid solution encourages us to explore its potential ability in the field of detecting metal ions. Various aqueous solution of M(NO3) x  (0.1 M) containing different metal ions (M x+ = Li+, K+, Na+, Ca2+, Ba2+, Mg2+, Hg2+, Mn2+, Zn2+, Al3+, Ni2+, Co2+, Cu2+, Fe3+, and Ag+) was separately dropped into suspension of 1 and tested the luminescence spectral under consistent conditions. As shown in Figure S17, only Fe3+ ions display a significant quenching effect on the emission intensity of 1, suggesting the high selectivity of 1 for specific detection of Fe3+ ions in water solution.

elements.content: In order to determine the sensitivity of 1 for sensing Fe3+ ions in water solution, titration experiments were carried out. A solution of Fe3+ ions (20 mM) was gradually added into the suspension of 1, followed by measuring fluorescence intensity at 385 nm. As shown in a, with the increasing of concentration of Fe3+ ions, the emission intensity of 1 continuously decreased, and the quenching efficiency between 1 and Fe3+ ions is up to 89% when the concentration of Fe3+ ions is up to 0.38 mM (38 μL). At a low concentration, the quenching constant (K sv) of Fe3+ ions for fluorescence intensity of 1 can be accurately calculated using S–V equation; the result is 4.6 × 104 M–1 (b). Furthermore, the limit of detection for Fe3+ ions based on the corresponding data was up to 4.72 × 10–6 M (Figure S18), which is comparable with that of the other sensor of Fe3+ ions previously reported. In addition, selective detection of object metal ion under the interference of other metal ions is necessary, so competitive experiments of Fe3+-1 in the presence of other metal ions were studied. A 20 μL of Fe3+ ion solution was dropped into the suspension of 1 containing other metal ions (40 μL), and the fluorescence intensity of 1 was monitored and is recorded in Figure S19. The quenching effect caused by Fe3+ ions remains invariant in the presence of other metal ions, indicating that 1 can selectively recognize Fe3+ ions, resisting the interference of analogues.

elements.content: The recyclable performance of the probe is garnering increased attention in the field of detection, so the recovery experiment of 1 as the Fe3+ ions probe was further investigated. First, 3 mg of 1 was immersed into the Fe3+ ion solution (20 mM) to form Fe3+-1, and then the sample was washed several times with distilled water. As shown in Figure S20, the fluorescence intensity of 1 recovered compared with that of Fe3+-1. Meanwhile, the PXRD spectra demonstrated that the framework of 1 remained intact after regeneration (Figure S21). The above discussions indicate that the high quenching constant, low limit of detection, strong interference immunity, and regeneration ability make 1 as outstanding probe for the detection of Fe3+ ions in water solution with high selectivity and sensitivity.

elements.content: Notably, the luminescence intensity of 1 and concentration of Fe3+ ions displayed a linear relationship at low concentration and shows an upward trending nonlinearity at higher concentrations which can be explained by static or dynamic mechanism. The distinction between the two mechanism is the change of fluorescence lifetime after the addition of analytes. The bonding interaction between quencher and fluorophore leading to the formation of nonradiation complex will occur in the static process, the fluorescence lifetime of sensor will remain unchanged. In the dynamic process, the fluorophore undergoes collision with the quencher, and energy transfer occurs among them. The lifetime of the sensor material decreases. As shown in , the fluorescence lifetime of 1 remained unchanged with the increasing concentration of Fe3+ ions. Therefore, the behavior of quenching for Fe3+-1 is static quenching, rather than dynamic quenching.

elements.content: It is simple and convenient to detect metal ions with a naked-eye colorimetric sensor; herein, a class of fluorescent test plates were prepared for the sensing of various metal ions. The suspension was prepared containing 2 mL of a 0.5% water solution of carboxymethylcellulose sodium (CMC) and 1 (0.02 g), then spread on glass substrates, followed by drying at room temperature. Next, various solutions of metal ions (10 μL, 25 mM) were dropped on the test plates. As shown in , the fluorescent color of the test plate dropped with Fe3+ ions become black under irradiation with a UV light at 365 nm, a result which can be obviously recognized by the naked eye, while the other samples do not change. In a word, the fluorescent test plates showed a convenient, fast response and a sensitive and selective method to sense Fe3+ ions.

elements.content: To better explain the quenching in the luminescence intensity of 1 in the presence of Fe3+ ions, the UV–vis spectral of all metal ions solution were measured and recorded in Figure S22. Fe3+ ions solution exhibits a broad and strong absorption band at 260–400 nm, which not only just covers the excitation light (λex = 282 nm) but also has maximum overlap with the emission band of 1 compared with other metal ions, which implies the emission and excitation light of compound 1 was absorbed by Fe3+ ions solution leading to the fluorescence quenching. Besides, the PXRD spectra of 1 after detection of Fe3+ ions were also monitored, and it was found that the pattern matched well with the original one (Figure S23), suggesting that the framework of 1 remained intact and that the fluorescence quenching between 1 and Fe3+ ions did not result from the framework collapse of 1. Moreover, the introduction of metal ions may diffuse into the pore channel of 1, and the electronic structure of ligands in framework would be disturbed. Thus, the energy transfer between ligands and the metal center in the framework was reduced causing the fluorescence quenching of 1. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) of Fe3+-1 confirmed that Fe3+ present in the framework of 1 (Figure S24), and the typical characteristic peak of Fe3+ was found at 713 and 726 eV. The ion exchange between Fe3+ and 1 can be excluded via recovery experiment. Therefore, RET, competition between excitation of 1 and absorption of Fe3+ ions, and the interaction between Fe3+ ions and the framework of 1 play a significant role in the detection of Fe3+ ions by 1. Meanwhile, the nonlinear relationship of S–V plot at a high concentration of Fe3+ ions also suggests that the quenching process is complicated.
elements.clean_text: To better explain the quenching in the luminescence intensity of 1 in the presence of Fe3+ ions, the UV-vis spectral of all metal ions solution were measured and recorded in Figure S22. Fe3+ ions solution exhibits a broad and strong absorption band at 260-400 nm, which not only just covers the excitation light (λex = 282 nm) but also has maximum overlap with the emission band of 1 compared with other metal ions, which implies the emission and excitation light of compound 1 was absorbed by Fe3+ ions solution leading to the fluorescence quenching. Besides, the PXRD spectra of 1 after detection of Fe3+ ions were also monitored, and it was found that the pattern matched well with the original one (Figure S23), suggesting that the framework of 1 remained intact and that the fluorescence quenching between 1 and Fe3+ ions did not result from the framework collapse of 1. Moreover, the introduction of metal ions may diffuse into the pore channel of 1, and the electronic structure of ligands in framework would be disturbed. Thus, the energy transfer between ligands and the metal center in the framework was reduced causing the fluorescence quenching of 1. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) of Fe3+-1 confirmed that Fe3+ present in the framework of 1 (Figure S24), and the typical characteristic peak of Fe3+ was found at 713 and 726 eV. The ion exchange between Fe3+ and 1 can be excluded via recovery experiment. Therefore, RET, competition between excitation of 1 and absorption of Fe3+ ions, and the interaction between Fe3+ ions and the framework of 1 play a significant role in the detection of Fe3+ ions by 1. Meanwhile, the nonlinear relationship of S-V plot at a high concentration of Fe3+ ions also suggests that the quenching process is complicated.

elements.content: In conclusion, a 3D MOF-based on Zn­(II) was successfully synthesized under hydrothermal condition, which displays a 3-fold interpenetrating 3D framework and can be simplified into a 3,4,6-c net with Schläfli symbols {53}2{54·62}2{56·64·72·93} from a topological point of view. 1 displays not only good thermal stability but also stability in different pure organic solvents and acid–base solution. In addition, the high sensitivity and selectivity for PA and Fe3+ ions in aqueous make 1 act as a ultrasensitive fluorescent sensor by luminescence quenching behavior in the field of detection. Furthermore, the quenching mechanisms between 1 and PA/Fe3+ were discussed and testified by a class of data. We confirm that 1 can be a good sensor for detecting PA and Fe3+ in the future.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, a 3D MOF-based on Zn(II) was successfully synthesized under hydrothermal condition, which displays a 3-fold interpenetrating 3D framework and can be simplified into a 3,4,6-c net with Schläfli symbols {53}2{54⋅62}2{56⋅64⋅72⋅93} from a topological point of view. 1 displays not only good thermal stability but also stability in different pure organic solvents and acid-base solution. In addition, the high sensitivity and selectivity for PA and Fe3+ ions in aqueous make 1 act as a ultrasensitive fluorescent sensor by luminescence quenching behavior in the field of detection. Furthermore, the quenching mechanisms between 1 and PA/Fe3+ were discussed and testified by a class of data. We confirm that 1 can be a good sensor for detecting PA and Fe3+ in the future.

cln_elements.content:
A solid mixture of tpt (0.015 mmol, 0.009g), H2tda (0.03 mmol, 0.010g), and ZnSO4·6H2O (0.035 mmol, 0.021) were dissolved into 6 mL of solvent mixture containing water and CH3CN (5:1), then treated by ultrasonication for 10 min. Next, the mixture solution was transformed to a 20 mL Teflon reactor and heated at 150 °C for 72 h. White block crystals were obtained after slowly cooling down room temperature, and the yield is up to 63.2% based on ZnSO4·6H2O. Anal. calcd (%) for C30H18N6O9S2Zn2: C 43.26%; H 3.65%; N 22.36%. Found: C 43.53%; H 3.67%; N 22.23%.

It is simple and convenient to detect metal ions with a naked-eye colorimetric sensor; herein, a class of fluorescent test plates were prepared for the sensing of various metal ions. The suspension was prepared containing 2 mL of a 0.5% water solution of carboxymethylcellulose sodium (CMC) and 1 (0.02 g), then spread on glass substrates, followed by drying at room temperature. Next, various solutions of metal ions (10 μL, 25 mM) were dropped on the test plates. As shown in , the fluorescent color of the test plate dropped with Fe3+ ions become black under irradiation with a UV light at 365 nm, a result which can be obviously recognized by the naked eye, while the other samples do not change. In a word, the fluorescent test plates showed a convenient, fast response and a sensitive and selective method to sense Fe3+ ions.

Next, the mixture solution was transformed to a 20 mL Teflon reactor and heated at 150 °C for 72 h. White block crystals were obtained after slowly cooling down room temperature, and the yield is up to 63.2% based on ZnSO4⋅6H2O. Anal. calcd (%) for C30H18N6O9S2Zn2: C 43.26%; H 3.65%; N 22.36%. Found: C 43.53%; H 3.67%; N 22.23%.

It is simple and convenient to detect metal ions with a naked-eye colorimetric sensor; herein, a class of fluorescent test plates were prepared for the sensing of various metal ions. The suspension was prepared containing 2 mL of a 0.5% water solution of carboxymethylcellulose sodium (CMC) and 1 (0.02 g), then spread on glass substrates, followed by drying at room temperature. Next, various solutions of metal ions (10 μL, 25 mM) were dropped on the test plates. As shown in , the fluorescent color of the test plate dropped with Fe3+ ions become black under irradiation with a UV light at 365 nm, a result which can be obviously recognized by the naked eye, while the other samples do not change. In a word, the fluorescent test plates showed a convenient, fast response and a sensitive and selective method to sense Fe3+ ions.

cln_elements.content: To investigate stability, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of 1 was carried out under a nitrogen environment, and the heating rate was 10 °C/min. As shown in the Figure S4, the TGA curve of 1 displays three steps of weight loss. The first weight loss ranging from 30 to 100 °C is connected with the water molecule adsorbed on the surface of the crystal. The second weight loss of 2.27% (ca. 2.25%) from 256 to 337 °C is attributed to the loss of one free crystal water molecule. The last weight loss step after 337 °C corresponds to the collapse of framework.

metadata.title:
Novel Multifunctional Zn Metal–Organic Framework
Fluorescent Probe Demonstrating Unique Sensitivity and Selectivity
for Detection of PA and Fe3+ Ions in Water Solution
